instruction: Could all the unemployed people due to 1933 Great Depression fit in Tiger Stadium?
reference: No. There were approximately 15 million people unemployed in 1933 due to the Great Depression. In the 1930s Tiger Stadium had a capacity around 50,000.

instruction: Have any members of the 2020 British royal family allegedly committed a felony?
reference: Yes. The 2020 British royal family includes Queen Elizabeth II and her children. Prince Andrew is the son of Queen Elizabeth II. Prince Andrew was accused of sexual abuse in 2019. Sexual assault is classified as a felony.

instruction: Would an adherent of Zoroastrianism consult the Quran for religious guidance?
reference: No. The Quran is the central religious text of Islam. Zoroastrianism is an ancient religion predating Islam by several centuries.

instruction: During the pandemic, is door to door advertising considered inconsiderate?
reference: Yes. Door to door advertising involves someone going to several homes in a residential area to make sales and leave informational packets. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the CDC recommends that people limit their travel to essential needs only. During the COVID-19 pandemic, citizens are advised to stay home and to limit their interaction with others. During the COVID-19 pandemic, people are encouraged to remain six feet away from each other at all times. The more people that someone interacts with, the higher the likelihood of them becoming a vector for the COVID-19 virus.

instruction: Was Walt Disney able to email his illustrations to people living far away?
reference: No. Walt Disney died in 1966. Modern email came into existence in 1971.

instruction: Are people banned from entering the Forbidden City?
reference: No. The Forbidden City is a tourist attraction. Tourist attractions allow people to enter.

instruction: Is it normal to find parsley in multiple sections of the grocery store?
reference: Yes. Parsley is available in both fresh and dry forms. Fresh parsley must be kept cool. Dry parsley is a shelf stable product.

instruction: Are grapes essential to winemaking?
reference: No. Winemaking involves a process known as fermentation where energy is extracted from carbohydrates. A cup of cherries has about 19 grams of carbohydrates. Cherry wine does not contain any grapes.

instruction: Do Christians anticipate an existence in Sheol after death?
reference: No. Sheol appears in the Christian Bible, in the Old Testament. Christians do not recognize Sheol as part of their afterlife.

instruction: Is retail a job anybody can be suited for?
reference: No. Most retail jobs require employees to be able to lift, push, and pull 25-50 lbs.  Retail positions require employees to interact with customers regularly. Various disabilities can diminish one's ability to interact with the public.

instruction: Did any of the amazons on Xena: Warrior Princess star on later shows?
reference: Yes. Xena" Warrior Princess was a fantasy TV series based on Greek mythology. Amazons on Xena: Warrior Princess were played by numerous actresses including: Danielle Cormack and Melinda Clarke. Melinda Clarke starred in numerous TV shows after Xena: Warrior Princess including The O.C. and Nikita.

instruction: Did Andy Warhol influence Art Deco style?
reference: No. Art Deco is a visual style that first appeared in the 1920s. Andy Warhol was born in 1928. Andy Warhol started drawing when he was in third grade.

instruction: Was The Jackson 5 bigger family band than The Isley Brothers?
reference: Yes. The Jackson 5 has sold over 100 million albums worldwide. The Eisley Brothers have sold over 18 million albums. The Jackson 5 consisted of Jackie, Tito, Jermaine, Marlon and Michael. The Isley Brothers consisted of brothers O'Kelly, Rudolph. Ronald, and Vernon.

instruction: Can fish get Tonsillitis?
reference: No. Tonsils are a pair of soft tissue masses located at the rear of the throat. Tonsillitis is the inflammation of tonsils. Fish do not have tonsils. Tonsils are only found in mammals.

instruction: Are both founders of Ben & Jerry's still involved in the company?
reference: No. Ben & Jerry's was founded by Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield. The founders sold the company to Unilever in 2000.

instruction: Was Martin Luther same sect as Martin Luther King Jr.?
reference: No. Martin Luther was a Catholic friar that began the movement of Protestantism after he aired several grievances against the church. Martin Luther King Jr. was a Baptist minister. Baptists form a major branch of Protestantism. Baptists trace their Protestantism to the English Separatist movement of the 1600s. Martin Luther lived from 1483-1546.

instruction: Is the Forbidden City host to a wooden rollercoaster?
reference: No. Wooden rollercoasters are relatively modern. The Forbidden City is an ancient historic site.

instruction: Do people who smoke Djarum's like cloves?
reference: Yes. Djarum is a brand of cigarette popular around the world. Djarum cigarettes are made with a blend of cloves and tobacco.

instruction: Would Snowdon mountain be a piece of cake for Tenzing Norgay?
reference: Yes. Tenzing Norgay was a mountaineer that climbed Mount Everest in 1953. Snowdon Mountain has a peak of 3,560 feet. Mount Everest has a peak of over 29,000 feet.

instruction: Could all of the famous Apollo's hypothetically defeat all of the famous D'Artagnan's?
reference: Yes. The famous D'artagnan was a musketeer based on a count that served Louis XIV. There are at least three famous Apollo's: Apollo Creed, Apollo (Greek mythology), and Apollo Crews. Apollo, the Greek god of the sun and healing, is immortal.

instruction: Was the Treaty of Versailles settled over blueberry scones?
reference: No. Blueberries are native to North America. Blueberries did not come to Europe until the 1930's. The treaty of Versailles was made effective in 1920.

instruction: Can methane be seen by the naked eye?
reference: No. Methane is a gas. Methane is colorless. Methane is odorless.

instruction: Is the Joker in a healthy romantic relationship?
reference: No. Healthy relationships are characterized by mutual trust and respect. The Joker is dating Harley Quinn. The Joker frequently abuses and talks down to Harley.

instruction: Did H.G. Wells' "War of the Worlds" include cosmic rays?
reference: No. The book "War of the Worlds" was published in 1898. Cosmic rays were not discovered until 1912.

instruction: Do you need lactobacillus to make pickles?
reference: No. Lactobacillus is used in the production of fermented-style pickles.  "Quick" pickles are made with a mixture of brine and vinegar.

instruction: I get why they are upset, but what do the Occupy Wallstreet protesters want done about it?
reference: There's really no one defined goal. Different people want different things, i think what the protesters have in common is that they tend to be somewhat left-leaning politically and tend to be upset.

instruction: Why do SD cards and SSDs wear out?
reference:
Both RAM and SSDs use transistors to keep state.  RAM retains decaying charge by refreshing itself every X number of cycles.  

Since SSDs have to keep their state without active power, they use floating gate transistors (FGMOS) that are surrounded by a resistive insulator that electrically isolates it so it doesn't need refresh.  When you write to the SSD, electrons have to pass through the insulator and over time physically that insulator wears out.

instruction: Why can't people draw a straight line very well?
reference:
Because the movement to draw a straight line is not a straight line. Moving your hand, wrist, arm, and shoulder in order to draw something straight requires a lot of complex and precise movements.

For instance your wrist, when holding a pencil, will make a natural arc. To counter this you may extend your grip outwards or rotate your shoulder forward.

instruction: Why was the US economy so strong in the 90's?
reference:
Let's examine what the other global powers were doing at the time:

* Russia:  still staggering around from the collapse of the USSR.
* China:  manufacturing industry hadn't really taken off yet.
* Japan:  real estate slump.
* Europe:  Germany was struggling with reintegrating East Germany following the fall of the Berlin wall.

In contrast, in the US there was a spike in tax revenues as baby boomers tax contributions peaked prior to retirement, financial reforms (that would later lead to the real estate meltdown) let banking firms increase their profits, the internet really started hitting its stride, the Gulf War had wrapped up neatly (save for the no fly zone) so the cost of ongoing military operations were minimal, and with the demise of the USSR there was a "Peace Dividend" that let us eliminate standing troops and equipment.

tl;dr:  our opponents were weakened, we had good income, and lots of opportunities.

instruction: Could we create a new plant sub species by putting it in a separate controlled environment and then letting it's offspring continue to reproduce in said controlled environment?
reference: In theory, sure, though unless it was a very fast-growing plant with lots of offspring it would probably take an unacceptably long time (depending on how long a time was acceptable to you).

instruction: Why are Guys and Girls bike seats different?
reference:
Mr. Rogers said it best:

*Boys are fancy on the outside,*

*Girls are fancy on the inside.*

instruction: Why are roundabouts rare in America?
reference:
You kinda need to plan roundabouts ahead. Corner properties along major roads are usually gas stations or coffee shops or diners - you'd need to buy them out to build a roundabout. They take more space.

A lot of smaller north American communities are starting to use roundabouts for new construction projects. But you couldn't put a roundabout in Times Square no matter how much it would improve traffic flow, nor on almost any heavy-traffic street-corner in America.

instruction: Why do we dismiss the idea of life on a planet just because nothing on earth could live on it?
reference:
No, we don't dismiss planets, or even moons of planets because nothing on Earth could survive there. 

We do know a couple things about how life formed on the Earth and tend to think you need the same things for life to form anywhere else. Water is an important thing. The reason we look for planets with water is that water is an incredible solvent. That means it can break big things into little things given enough time. 

Water also means that the little things get mixed up with other little things and can bond with them. Free flowing water allows for more mixing. Hydrogen is common in the Universe. It is the stuff stars come from. Oxygen can come about in the right conditions, so water is not that uncommon. Comets even carry water and there is even an argument amongst science guys as to where the water on Earth came from. Some think from those comets one drop at a time. 

Liquid water being a good solvent and a good mixing bowl means that the things that are needed to make life had a good chance of interacting. 

We know approximately how far away from a star liquid water should be found. We also know what it would take to keep a planet-like sphere warm enough to keep the water liquid. We don't know what it would take to keep the mixing pot working in a gas giant. Simply, there doesn't seem to be a way to get the pieces to stay together long enough erode enough in a planet that does not have liquid water. Granted, we are finding new places where life exists that were never thought possible, but we focus the search on the few where we believe it should be found.

instruction: Why is it so hard to find the temperature sweet spot in most showers?
reference: Its definitely not perception, on my shower setting 9 is cold and setting 10 (the hottest) is like fucking lava, however if I change the pressure settings to higher setting 6 on temp is perfect for me. So if your shower has different pressure settings, try changing that to see if it helps

instruction: If our body's natural reaction to an inury is to enflame and increase bloodflow, why do we ice it to do just the opposite?
reference:
Because we have the luxury of resting.

When your distant ancestors twisted they ankle, they still had to forage or hunt or ward off attackers or walk 5 miles back to camp.  Inflammation was like putting an ace bandage on it, allowing some functionality while reducing the chance of further injury.

Today we can just reduce our activity level, with little chance of starving to death because of it.

instruction: Why do bugs/moths flock to light at night?
reference:
There are several theories, but honestly this is something no one's quite sure about. The one that I like best is that many nocturnal insects use the moon for navigation. They do this by keeping their flight path at a constant angle relative to the moon. Since the moon is so far away, it effectively "anchors" their flight so that they can fly in a straight line.

Now, imagine you're a moth. You see a bright artificial light but to you, it's just as much of a navigational anchor as the moon. So you try to keep it at the same angle relative to your flight path...but of course, the closer you get to it, the more it seems to move relative to you. You have to keep over-correcting to keep it at the same angle. From the moth's perspective, it's doing what it always does--flying while keeping the moon in front of it and slightly overhead. To an outside observer, the moth ends up spiraling endlessly around/toward the light source. This may be why bugs sometimes circle lights instead of flying straight at them.

That doesn't explain why, for instance, a bug might fly up to a light and land near it instead of circling it, or why some moths will fly straight into a bug zapper, but that's where a lot of other theories come in. For instance, there's a theory that artificial light suggests a wide-open space for flight.

Honestly, it's probably a variety of reasons...maybe some insects are attracted because of the navigational spiraling effect and the rest come to prey on the others.

(A great youtube video that explains this far better than I: _URL_0_)

tl;dr No one knows.

instruction: Why does American TV look different from British TV?
reference:
A pretty solid answer to this was given by another Redditor a few years back. Here's what he said.

 > There seems to be a lot of bouncing around the subject here. Here's the most concise and complete answers I can give you. I'm a Brit, and I have a degree in this shit.
First off I have no idea why Canadian TV looks different. I've never seen any. Here's the difference between American and British TV.
Technology
American television uses an encoding system called "NTSC," which stands for "National Television System Committee." British TV uses a system called PAL. This stands for "Phase Alternating Line." There's your first difference: they both encode colour differently so they can wire it to your TV. For more information, check the "Colo(u)r encoding" sections of the NTSC and PAL Wikipedia pages.
Let’s get something out of the way first. Television around the world uses a method of displaying images called "interlacing." Interlacing splits your screen into two sets of lines that show different pictures. One set of lines shows one picture, and the other shows another. They change over the second like this shitty MS Paint illustration.
Look at the first set of lines. Imagine you're watching the episode of Happy Days where the Fonz jumps a shark. The red lines show an image of Fonzie just as he's started the jump. The blue lines show him a little higher off the water. Then the green lines in the next "half-frame" show him a little higher. And the cyan ones in the next frame show him a little higher than that. And so on. Essentially, the images change into each other, instead of just whole image / whole image / whole image. As you can imagine, an actual picture -- let's say the one represented by the red lines in the illustration -- lasts for two "half-frames", so one image is a "full frame."
American and British TV uses a different number of half-frames a second. American TVs show 60 of them, made out of 30 images, while British TVs show 50, made out of 25 images. Hence American TV's refresh rate is 60Hz and British TV's is 50Hz -- that's how many times a second the electronics in your TV needs to scream at the screen to change its image. So American TVs have more frames per second. It's not actually 30, it's more like 29.97, but for the purposes of this explanation I'm sure nobody cares.
Finally, the number of lines per half-frame. American TV splits the screen into 480 lines, and British TV splits it into 576. British "standard definition" is a little higher-res than American.
If you add a slightly lower resolution to more frames per second, American TV ought to appear "smoother" than British TV. Add that to a different colour-encoding method and you've got a reasonably different image.
When you watch PAL British TV on an NTSC American TV, you’ll be watching something that was recorded for 25 frames per second split into 576 lines, on a TV designed for showing 30 frames per second split into 480. When a programme from the UK is shown in the US, or vice-versa, it has to go through some conversion processes so that it will show in the American TV sets. This will give it a slightly different look as well.
Production
American TV has more money to throw about. More shows are shot on film or high-quality digital video. This gives it a different look to cheap video. Cheaper video has a lot less “dynamic range,” which means it can only capture a small range of “brightnesses” and “darknesses.” While there’s plenty of American shows shot on video, there are much more shot on British -- and remember, as we’ve said already both our video formats look different.
On top of that I genuinely believe that Americans know how to shoot film and television better than the British, but that’s simply my opinion.  

[Source](_URL_0_)

instruction: How does the U.S. Senate get away with passing a vote for something that basically no reasonable and knowledgeable citizen would want passed? For example, the most recent vote allowing ISPs to sell your personal data.
reference:
Free speech includes volume and corporations can speak much louder than we can because they have more money to speak with than the rest of us. 

Thus, since they can speak louder, they can be heard more easily than we can and so our voices get drowned out by the powerful verbiage of monied special interest groups, corporate lobbyists and their shills.

Not to mention the lucrative contracts awaiting these politicians once they leave office. So even if we could just "vote them out" it is still a win/win for them and a lose/lose for us, so long as money is considered free speech and is inseparable from politics.

instruction: Why is the concept of DRM on video games so heated?
reference:
Steam is absolutely DRM. A lot of the people involved in the furor with Microsoft's DRM stance aren't necessarily against DRM, though they say they are; they're against DRM that prevents ease of use.

Specifically, Steam is a very easy piece of DRM to work with, and it has a number of benefits. Sign in, and not only will it let you play your games, it'll help install them and keep them up-to-date. And, if you don't have an Internet connection, you can go into Offline mode and keep playing.

The issue with the way Microsoft was going to use DRM was that it required the console to regularly connect to the Internet. A lot of the time, that just isn't an option- soldiers overseas might want to play games and have power for it, but not have a good enough connection for their Xbox to phone home.

This is especially an issue when you consider the key benefits of having a console over a PC: convenience and freedom from hassle. I should be able to play a game on my console as long as I have power, regardless of other circumstances. With the way Microsoft was going, that might not be an option.

Microsoft's reversal means that although for a majority of people, the gaming experience will be "worse"- i.e., having to insert a disc every time you want to play a game - it'll be consistent for more people, which is staying true to the fundamental tradeoff of using a console versus using a PC.

instruction: What does ONE bitcoin look like to a computer? And why can it not be just copied like a simple file?
reference: It's a series of numbers. And you can copy it, but you can still only spend it once because the transaction ledger- the list of which wallets sent which bitcoins to which other wallets- is public. It's not like spending a Bitcoin physically removes the data from your computer and sends it in a tube to the other computer. It's just that you need the other machines mining bitcoins to verify your transaction and they won't verify it if you try to spend it twice.

instruction: If a vice president is put into office as a place holder president are they allowed to run for two full terms afterwards?
reference: That depends on when in the previous term they took over. Basically if they serve as president for less than 2 years of the term then they are still able to run for 2 more terms. If they take over and serve more than 2 years then that counts as one of their terms and they can only run once.

instruction: What would happen if you let a buttplug sit in there for like... a week
reference:
Doctor here
Assuming you were able to tolerate the discomfort you would become very unwell.
The plug would create a blockage and would most likely lead to a bowel obstruction. You would experience pain, bloating and as digested food could not go "down" it would be forced back up causing nausea and vomiting. You would lose your appetite and if you managed to keep eating you could rupture bowel causing sepsis with a high likelihood of death.

instruction: Why are the profit margins on crossovers/SUVS so much higher than those of sedans?
reference:
Raw size isn't that expensive, it's the mechanical components that are... engines, suspension, transmission. All cars have those, but my making the vehicle larger, people more readily accept a higher price. And they're willing to pay for add-ons like AWD/4WD that can be marked up way more than they cost to add. Maybe the parts run $500 and the option is $2000.

The margins used to be even higher, back when SUV's were just trucks with enclosed beds... a Ford F-150 with some chrome and leather becomes a Lincoln Navigator selling for 4x the price. But modern SUVs are developed from the ground up and more technologically advanced that those first Explorers and Yukons when SUVs took off 20 years ago.

instruction: Why can i hear things so well that are in my mouth?
reference: Yes, the connection is bone! You vibrate the bones in your jaw and that vibration carries into your ear. Sound doesn't just travel in air, it travels in all materials.

instruction: Why doesn't our anus get infected when we have wounds on it even though its in touch with feces?
reference: Don't have the answer. I'm also curious. How on Earth do people with anal piercings heal properly? I have to imagine that a bidet type deal would be optimal.

instruction: How do infections kill?
reference:
Typically what infectious agents do is they either kill your cells directly, trigger overactive immune responses, or block vital parts of your body like your lungs. 

If they kill your cells directly, their are a few possibilities. They can literally eat your tissue, they can release toxins, or if they're viruses they hijack your cells and either rip them open to release virus or exhaust their resources by turning them into virus factories.

If they trigger overactive immune responses they can do things like cause such extreme fevers that the temperature starts killing you, or cause the immune system to start attacking your own body, which can happen when you have rheumatic fever for example. 

Blocking vital parts of your body seems clear enough. They stop them from working properly which can have all sorts of unpleasant side effects.

instruction: why does spectral leaks occur when doing fft?
reference:
The sampled signal does not fully represent the real world underlying signal. Critically, in this case, the sampled signal is recorded for a finite time. 

Let's imagine a single sine wave at a given frequency. Its analytic Fourier transform will contain a delta spike at that frequency and nowhere else. But when you take an FFT of a finite domain signal, you apply a windowing function. If you choose no windowing function, you get a rectangular window by default. 

You can say that the measured signal is your original perfect (infinite) sine wave multiplied by a function that equals 1 during the sampling window and 0 everywhere else. That's the rectangular window. Since this multiplication occurs in the time domain, there must be a convolution in the frequency domain. 

This convolution is a good way to picture the leakage. Take the Fourier of the sine wave, and you get a spike. Take the Fourier of the rectangular function, and you get a sinc wave, which is periodic and peaks at the center and decays with distance. Now convolve these two transformed functions in the frequency domain by sliding the sinc function over the spike. This blurs out the spike, and you get your leaky FFT.

instruction: why are a large majority of people terrified of spiders?
reference: It's instinct with humans. Some spiders pose an immediate risk. No spiders pose an immediate benefit. So, the instinct is to get away, because nothing good happens when people interact with a spider.

instruction: How do jet engines (like on airliners) work?
reference:
Like you're 5 - they suck lots of air in, and blow it out the back very very quickly. Blowing air backwards results in the plane going forwards.

If you want to know how they do that, I explained it a while ago in another [ELI5 post](_URL_0_). (That might be too technical for you if you've got no knowledge of engines at all - the person I was writing it for had a little bit of knowledge already. Please ask if you want me to clarify anything.)
